title: Braised Short Rib
description: A pepper-heavy wine braise. The garlic paste is the whole trick — it penetrates the meat in a way whole cloves can't.
source: Chef John's Peposa dell'Impruneta, with adaptations

items.note: alternative: anything with collagen who cares
coarsely ground; with quality pepper you don't need separate ground and crushed
most of a head, just use a fuckton

items.item: pearl onions, carrot, celery, onion, bell pepper, potato
items.note: add them at the right time, not the wrong one

directions.text: Salt short ribs. You may sear them but need not. I sometimes sear them and use the fond for something else entirely, then use the seared ribs with a fondless pot. Chaos.
Turn the garlic into a paste using salt and a mortar and pestle. A garlic press works fine too — the mortar probably makes a difference but life is short.
Rub short ribs with garlic paste and tomato paste. Get messy.

Fill your Dutch oven with ribs in a single layer. Add wine until it comes almost to the top of the meat — 2 cups is a safe minimum but use more if needed. Add all the herbs n shit. Braise tightly covered, about 3.5 hours, turning every 30 mins or so. Set timers or forget and panic.
Serve with polenta or mashed potato or something. Top with parsnip chips if you're feeling fancy.

notes: Wine only, no beef broth. This is what makes the recipe — comes out way better than broth-based braises.
What the right time is for adding vegetables is left as an exercise to the reader.
The longer you braise, the more the meat falls off the bone. 3.5 hours is minimum; 4+ is better if you have time.

deviations.what: Garlic paste instead of whole cloves
deviations.why: More intense flavor distribution. The paste penetrates the meat surface; whole cloves just sit next to it.

deviations.what: Just coarsely ground pepper instead of separate ground and crushed
deviations.why: With quality pepper, one coarse grind gives you both the integration and the texture. Simpler.
